It suppose relationship postprandial inflammatory response repartition fat lean mass , could partially explain muscle mass loss age . The aim study compare inflammatory response normal meal high fat meal ( different fatty acid source ) young lean young obese age lean age obese men .
DOC.brief_title: Postprandial Inflammatory Response Healthy Men : Effect Dietary Fat Source , Obesity Age
DOC.detailed_description: 32 healthy volunteer separate four group : 8 young lean men , 8 young obese men , 8 age lean men 8 age obese men . They come center four time inclusion , 2 4 week wash time . At first visit undergo different test evaluate body composition , glucose tolerance , rest energy expenditure , muscular strength . At three visit , people undergo kinetic blood sampling , urine biopsy adipose tissue period 8h ingestion test meal . The different meal test ( Oleic acid vs palmitic acid v lipid ) give random way three visit . Before three visit , control diet establish . At last visit body composition muscular strength evaluate .
DOC.criteria: Subject give write informed consent Male 20 35 year old 60 Affiliated French National Health Insurance Body mass index ( BMI ) ≤ 25kg/m² waist circumference ≤94cm ; BMI ≥ 28kg/m² waist circumference ≥ 102cm . Complete blood count ( CBC ) platelet , normal liver function normal coagulation . Serology Human immunodeficiency virus ( HIV ) hepatitis C virus ( HCV ) negative normal Thyroid Stimulating Hormone ( TSH ) Previous medical and/or surgery judge investigator incompatible study Glaucoma Creactive protein > 10 mg/l people 120 kg People triglyceridemia > 3 g/L familial hypercholesterolemia Fasting glycemia > 1,26 g/l , abnormal Oral Glucose Tolerance Test Dietary habit judge dietitian incompatible study aim Vegetarians Nutritional allergy xylocaïn allergy People eat disorder Heavy consumer alcohol cigarette Practising intensive physical exercise People medication could interfere measure parameter : betablockers , statin , anticoagulant , antiplatelet agent , corticosteroid 8 day .
